text: Market stalls line both sides of the street, the scents of grilled fish, spices, and fresh flowers mingling with drifting smoke.
The steady rhythm of hammering from the blacksmith blends with voices and wind, forming a warm, lively chorus.
“I thought you could barely walk. Didn’t expect you to move faster than me.”
I glance toward a grilled fish stall nearby. “That smell is unfair.”
Alicia sighs in mock exasperation, yet follows me over to the stand.
She pulls out a few coins. “One for him.”
I pay first. The vendor grins and hands over the skewers, the scent of charcoal thick in the air.
Alicia pauses, then accepts the fish, glancing at me.
“Since when did you become so attentive?”
“Someone saved my life the other day. Figured I should return the favor somehow.”
She lets out a soft laugh and says nothing more.
Sunlight brushes her profile as the aroma of grilled fish and the murmur of the crowd wrap around us—brief, but unmistakably real peace.
